Re-assessing the risks and opportunities from North Korea
We believe recent events in the Korean Peninsula warrant a revisit of the risks and opportunities posed by North Korea. Given the innate difficulty in predicting the outcome, we introduce three broad scenarios, the key signposts and the stock implications thereof. We view economic impact of reforms in North Korea, if it were to happen, to be more relevant to South Korea and less so regionally and globally. We keep our 2018 KOSPI target unchanged as we view geopolitics unlikely to materially rerate or derate the index.

What will happen to North Korea?
We do not know. But we introduce three scenarios and markers that we believe could help us understand its evolution, focused on the economic impact. Scenario 1 is status quo, where the border remains closed and impact to South Korea is marginal. Scenario 2, two peaceful independent states, would give trading partners access North Korea's well educated but cheaper labour (1/23 the labour cost in South Korea), and its nascent domestic market. Scenario 3, reunification is a high-risk, potentially high-return case, in our view, as South Korea would see most of the benefits and majority of the risks.

The key signposts and the implications from history
We view signposts to include fulfilling the agreement made in US-North Korea Summit (12 June), a possible peace treaty and reforms in North Korea. The experience of transitional economies suggests North Korea's GDP could grow rapidly if it were to shift to a market economy, similar to Vietnam (12.7% CAGR since 1990) after it launched the Doi Moi policy (1986). But we view the impact to be largely limited to South Korea given the small size of North Korea's GDP (cUS$18bn). For South Korea, Scenario 2 would be reminiscent to Hong Kong and Taiwan's experiences in mainland China, with competition and rule of law being the key risks. Scenario 3 would be similar to German reunification, with capital transfer from South to North, inflation and interest rate being some of the risks South Korea may face.

Impact on South Korean equities
We maintain our 2018 KOSPI target of 2,650 (10x 2018E PE) as North Korea is not the only reason for the market’s discount, in our view. But we see opportunities for select sectors in the medium/long term that have not played out, depending on the outcome of the negotiation. Still, we expect a pull-back in North Korea-themed stocks (Figure 14) under all three scenarios, as we view the recent rally overdone and believe it will be short-lived, similar to German equities.

One of the reasons a SYK for BSX transaction is so surprising is that both companies have talked down the need for scale and pointed to their own success (both in terms of revenue/EPS growth and stock performance; see Chart 1) as reasons that a strategy focused more on tuck-in deals and faster growing niches is preferred. In fact, the poster child for the acquisition for scale strategy, MDT, has noted that broad bundling doesn’t really work yet as hospitals still largely buy in clinical silos. Having said that, there is certainly logic to being a bigger player in a consolidating healthcare landscape and so
an argument for bulking up is also supportable—it just isn’t clear it’s the better strategy. For SYK, diversification away from the slower growth orthopedic segments has been in the works for years, though it has come through smaller deals. A combo with BSX would
dramatically broaden the portfolio into cardiology, urology and neuromodulation among others, but it also could make it harder to grow faster than the underlying markets. The basic questions are why the companies feel it’s time to capitulate on scale? If they do, can they make the case that the future for such a company is better than what they had been doing all along -- can one $25bn company perform as well as two companies half that size? And perhaps most importantly, will investors value them the same?

[T]he valuation on the four mega-cap deals are all below where BSX and SYK trade as independent companies. With full acknowledgement that every situation is different, it suggests that even with the accretion from the deal we outline below, the fall in valuation could more than offset the bump in EPS. As an example, our model shows 8% accretion in 2020 to $9.33
for SYK with BSX. Applying an 18x-19x instead of the current 22x would put SYK shares at
$168-$177 or roughly in line with current valuation.

BE11:31am

And Goldman.

BE11:32am

While we take no view on the likelihood of a deal, we see
limited business overlap (primary overlap in endoscopy products, where both SYK and BSX generate $1.6bn revenue in their respective endoscopy segments) that could prevent such a deal from an antitrust perspective.
If a deal were to be consummated, we see the potential for significant benefits in terms of scale. For illustrative purposes, a combined SYK/BSX would make it the #5 Med Tech company by revenue with $21.5Bn pro forma CY17 sales. That said, revenue synergies would be more difficult to assess as the two companies share little product overlap and only modest channel overlap. In addition, we note that nearly 40% of combined pro-forma revenue would be in what we expect to be very low growth categories (ortho, CRM, stents). For context, precedent large cap Med Tech deals have been completed in a range of 3.2-6.3x LTM Sales and 12.9-20.7x LTM EBITDA

While the shares may appear cheap relative to others in the sector, we don’t see a near-term catalyst to close the valuation gap. We maintain our forecasts and Hold recommendation.

Interim results look broadly in line with our expectations, albeit slightly below at the PBT level. DPS has been kept flat at the interim stage, and we had expected modest growth.
Overall, the outlook comments are very much in line with the comments made in the
recent trading update. The group still expects revenue growth of over 15% for the full
year and margins to be around 18%. The risk to us remains more on FY2019E estimates
with a big step up on revenues expected again and margins flat at 18%. Clearly the
market at their price point remains difficult and the group will continue to mitigate the impact on margins. We do not expect consensus to change materially today but the higher end may edge back. The shares look to be good value but it's difficult to get too excited in the near term with a lack of momentum for profits and earnings, and still some downside risk for FY2019E estimates in our view. Overall, results and comments look broadly as expected.

Following the profit warning in March we indicated that something needed to change at Greencore. Since then we have had a shift in focus in US strategy further towards contract manufacturing with CPG customers, and more recently news that it is seeking to hire a CEO for its US business. We regard both as encouraging developments. Combined with the good underlying performance of the business in H1 2018, we believe a change in view is warranted, and upgrade to Add increasing the TP from 138p to 210p. This equates to 14x PE for CY 2018, in line with its 5 year average. We believe that the strength of the Greencore's competitive position and the underlying growth fundamentals in both the UK and the US arguably deserve a higher multiple. Recent issues on guidance and a lack of consistent financial performance remain a concern and temper our enthusiasm.

Q1 is only forecast to represent c19% of full year sales, hence the absolute revenue beat is not likely to cause much excitement, although the momentum at PLT and Nasty Gal (+149%) should. Similarly, we gain confidence from the strong GM performance. We leave our top-of-the-range forecasts unchanged, but can see the consensus PBT of £64m moving closer to our £68m.

BE12:08pm

Why Domino’s Pizza Group cannot hold onto their Finance Directors is a very good and valid question. Since the departure of Lee Ginsberg, who was a long standing and highly recognised FD, the group has churned through three since 2015 and with the announcement today that Rachel Osborne has handed in her resignation effective 11 June 2018, the group are on to their fourth. We question whether there is an internal cultural issue, whether she cannot see a path to maximising her remuneration scheme or other issues? Whatever the answer is, it does not look good and begs corporate governance questions. In a year when the CEO’s LTIPS vest we would like to see a more detailed analysis of the EPS support provided by share buybacks, M&A and underlying performance and on what basis and why the LTIPS are calculated.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Our concerns on the sustainability of the model remain where area splits are unsustainable in our view (c.11 year paybacks for franchisees). In a drive to higher earnings the group is buying back shares at 25x PE which we ask if that is really in the interests of shareholders - we know it is LTIP supportive in the current year. From an M&A perspective we think the Plc is likely to make more acquisitions be it franchisees in the UK but could more likely in Ireland and these could be in a JV form so as to retain current management teams. These kind of deals would not necessarily change our recommendation but the price paid should also provide an indicative payback period that shareholders should expect from such investment - are these in line with what they expect the franchisees to bear? No long term targets have been given on any of the Group’s new markets, deals or M&A and we ask how it can be in shareholders’ interests to be buying back shares at current levels. Considering today’s shock announcement highlights that all is not good internally. While the share performance has clearly gone against our SELL, we retain this.
